text: hey everyone this is my high vacuum pen
engage I have this connected to my
scanning electron microscope so that I
can read what the high vacuum level is
when the microscope is running so in a
pinch if you remember when one of my
recent videos I said that I was having
trouble with this gauge so I decided to
take it apart and try to figure out
what's wrong and the way this is built
is there's a metal to metal contact here
and instead of using a rubber o-ring to
seal the vacuum in this device comes
with a crushable metal seal so I was
refurbishing this gauge at one point and
didn't have the special crushable metal
seal to put in there so what I did is I
just put plain old rosin core flux in
there because this is you know mostly
led and it's soft so that when you
squeeze the two halves together this
crushes down and you get a nice metal to
metal seal I knew that the rosin core
was going to be a problem but but check
it out now this actually performed just
fine for a number of years but
eventually the rosin got squeezed out
and as you can see it's actually
starting to enter the the ion chamber of
this gauge here so if I you know peel
this up a little bit you can kind of see
how flat the solder is and the metal is
probably doing a good job sealing it's
just that the rosin was causing some
outgassing in there and polluting the
vacuum gauge so to fix this I bought
some pure indium wire off of ebay and
this stuff is super super soft much
softer than lead it's kind of expensive
so I don't want to waste a piece but
basically just pulling on it you can
pull this piece apart inside the pen
engage there is an electrode here so
it's really just a two wire device and
there's my solder seal on the other side
and there are two magnets that create a
field in here so that electrons flowing
between these two electrodes have a
spiral path although interestingly
inside the gauge there's this little
thin metal shield so the magnets are in
here and then there's this thin metal
shield here and as you can see
the course of the ions actually causes a
little bit of destruction on the shield
the rainbow color has come from a film
that's been deposited on the inside of
this shield here and the thickness of
the film is comparable to the wavelength
of light so I don't know what the film
is it actually might be solder rosin
rosin flux and you know which leaks into
the chamber and then the ions the the
high voltage supplied to this thing
causes the ions to accelerate and
deposit some of the rosen on the balls
here so I'm going to clean all this out
as best I can and then reassemble it
with the Indian wire seal and then hook
it up to my new vacuum rig that I'm
building right now
the pen engage works by putting a high
voltage between that Center electrode
that flat plate and the outer body which
is the other electrode and then
measuring how much current passes
through the through the lower atmosphere
that this whole thing is exposed to so
the vacuum can chamber connects to here
and this whole chamber is at the vacuum
chamber pressure the idea is that the
lower the pressure the less current will
be conducted for a given voltage and the
reason for that is that there are just
fewer carriers fewer ions your nitrogen
molecules and oxygen molecules to carry
the current from the center electrode to
the housing and the whole point of the
magnets is in this thing is just to make
the path length longer so if there were
no magnets the Elector the ions would
carry straight from that Center
conductor out to the out to the outside
and that's only you know a few
millimeters three four millimeters in
there with the magnets the path is
helical so the magnets caused the
charged particles to swirl around okay
I'll keep you posted on my new vacuum
rig see you next time bye
